So the thesis of the talk is fairly simple.
I believe that data mining has made tremendous strides in last decade and it is time to take data mining to the next level of contributions.
To do so, we will need to develop new abstractions.
New algorithms, new systems and they have to be inspired by new applications and conferences such as CI Cam which are interdisciplinary in nature.
Are going to play a crucial role in this.

So the outline is I'm going to give try to give a little progress report why I believe that data mining has made tremendous strides and then talk about some of the things I feel are important or will become important or likely to become important future.
So this is roughly the snapshot of progress.
Basically I was asked to give a keynote at KDD conference in.
I guess 1999 and that at that time I had argued that basically we have to make progress along these dimensions.

System support, algorithmics innovations, foundations, usability, enterprise applications and something that I call unanticipated applications an you see these green bars which have been very scientifically determined indicator of the progress.
What I'm going to do is essentially not try to cover all of them, but say a few words about system support and something about algorithmics innovations.
Also want to mention something about applications, but spend a little bit more time on what I consider things that we didn't anticipate.
An and those are the places where data mining has started to find very, very large applications.
OK, so getting on the first thing has to do with system support.
I think if you go back and look into papers around 1995 or so there was a lot of research activity in terms of how we're going to integrate all these data.
Data mining technologies with data systems they were initially created as separate tools and it was very difficult to develop applications because they will not interoperate with other.

Other applications that companies were developing, so these were sort of the toy applications and very interesting research happened, but the end result now is that if you look into sort of major database vendors, you know we'd Oracle beat IBM with Microsoft.
They all have integrated data mining capabilities into their database software and the result is that you can essentially write and develop very, very interesting applications.
Which run at the enterprise skin.
The other thing that happened was that in parallel, people have started to develop very very interesting data mining plaque platforms.

An Premier example of it is Google's data binding platform, but but if you look at other other search companies they have developed very similar kind of platforms, you know.
I mean Microsoft has something called Riot.
Hadoop is being used by the search engines and so on and a lot delve into it.

At a scale which you know, frankly speaking, nobody had thought you will be able to do that.
So this is sort of straightforward.
But this is something which hasn't yet happened as much but.

They will stay solvent, and yet you want to essentially do do knowledge again.
Again, information from these databases and you want to do it in such a way that there's some notion of minimal information sharing which is respected.

Think like you're trying to do intersection between two lists.

One list is something like a Security Agency which has list of people they consider suspect for some reasons, and another list might be owned by an airline airline.
You know there's a vested interest in finding out.
If somebody is flying who is in the watch list of this particular Security Agency, but clearly a Security Agency would not like their complete list to be known by the airline.

How should we essentially do this work?
So this notion of minimal information sharing is respected and which basically says?

So if you think about it underneath, technology is pretty straightforward.

The initial few algorithms looked at all the log of queries which have been asked in the past and try to give as related searches those queries which were high frequency queries which contain the query term.

So in this case, if baseball was the query they will go and see in the log water the queries where baseball was appearing as a substring Ann and Major League Baseball is an example of such strength, so it's pretty straightforward.
Go and go into the log, find out.
What are the what are the popular queries show that's suggestion and the idea is the following that if a lot of people are asking these particular query queries, this is how they're refining it.

So the other idea was to then start doing session analysts is where you see how people have gone and reformulated the queries in the past.
So if you see that people have gone and refund, you know they initially asked football and then they reformulated the query to say soccer.
Then that's a good indication that lot of people perhaps want to do this particular reformulation, an offer that as a suggestion.

I think the next thing what is happening here is is this notion of orthogonal related queries.

So not only you want to show queries, you in some sense want to show queries which represent concepts which in some sense are orthogonal, meaning thereby that there's no point trying to give lot of suggestions which lead to the same pages but try to give suggestions.
Which leads to different aspect of this particular query.
